docs.lead_paragraph: More men than women become compulsive gamblers, but a number of other behavior differences were found in a recent study of addictive betting. The study, by Yale researchers and published last week in The American Journal of Psychiatry, analyzed data from 562 callers to a telephone hot line for problem gamblers in Connecticut.
docs.abstract: Yale University study probes differences between men and women who like to gamble (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Carol Cotter vividly remembers the time when, as a squeamish 14-year-old, she had to help her grandmother put in her false teeth. ''I thought, 'I don't ever want that to happen to me,' '' said Ms. Cotter, 58, a social worker in Marlboro, N.J.

headline.main: Goodbye, Dentures: Improved Dental Implants Gaining Favor

docs.abstract: Dental implants grow more popular; number of implant procedures has tripled in last 10 years; about two million implants are done each year; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: Voice problems are an occupational hazard for telemarketers, according to a study by researchers from the University of Nebraska Medical Center in Omaha. About a third of workers in industrialized nations rely on their voices to get their jobs done, and as call centers have proliferated, voice clinics have had more visits from telemarketers, the study said.

headline.main: The Side Effects of Speaking for a Living

docs.abstract: Study finds that voice problems are occupational hazard for telemarketers (S)
docs.snippet: Voice problems are an occupational hazard for telemarketers, according to a study by researchers from the University of Nebraska Medical Center in Omaha.    About a third of workers in industrialized nations rely on their voices to get their jobs...

docs.lead_paragraph: People who had lost the ability to speak because of a stroke improved more quickly when they were given low doses of an amphetamine along with speech therapy, according to a study published Thursday in the journal Stroke. The study, led by Dr. Delaina Walker-Batson of Texas Woman's University in Dallas, built on research in animals that had found that brain injuries healed faster when the animals were given drugs, like amphetamines, that increased the release of a chemical called norepinephrine.
docs.abstract: Study finds that people who had lost ability to speak because of a stroke improve more quickly when they are given low doses of an amphetamine along with speech therapy (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Two or three times a week, 9-year-old Lauren Ross of Biloxi, Miss., goes through an intensive exercise routine designed by her father. The two-hour program includes stretching, jumping exercises and a little weight lifting. It is all in preparation for Lauren's fall season as a speedy forward on the Shooting Stars soccer team.

headline.main: Protecting the Knees of Athletic Girls Long Before the Whistle Blows

docs.abstract: Comment on increased awareness of knee injuries afflicting schoolgirl athletes playing sports like soccer, and on efforts to practice prevention; there has been alarming increase in number of athletes suffering serious knee injury called torn anterior cruciate ligament; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: A new Australian study has found that adolescents who are bullied, especially girls, are more likely to develop emotional problems. The study by researchers from the Royal Children's Hospital in Victoria was based on surveys given twice, a year apart, to nearly 3,000 students in their early teens.
docs.abstract: New Australian study finds that adolescents who are bullied, especially girls, are more likely to develop emotional problems (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: People with multiple sclerosis often report that their symptoms worsen when they feel hot, and researchers have experimented with cooling vests or caps. Now a new study published in this month's issue of Neurology confirms that lowering temperature does in fact help, and offers a possible explanation.
docs.abstract: New study confirms that lowering body temperature helps relieve symptoms of people with multiple sclerosis (S)
docs.snippet: People with multiple sclerosis often report that their symptoms worsen when they feel hot, and researchers have experimented with cooling vests or caps.    Now a new study published in this month's issue of Neurology confirms that lowering...

docs.lead_paragraph: Researchers at the University of Florida reported today that transplanting human embryonic or fetal tissue into people with spinal cord injuries appeared to be safe. The study is the first in the United States to perform such implants in humans. In two papers released today in The Journal of Neurotrauma, research scientists at the university's McKnight Brain Institute report that the first two patients to undergo the procedure have experienced no ill effects. The research involved spinal cord cells from late embryos or early fetuses -- an embryo becomes a fetus at about eight weeks -- not stem cells, which have the potential to develop into many cell types.

headline.main: Fetal Tissue Implanted Safely, Doctors Say

docs.abstract: Researchers at the University of Florida report that transplanting human embryonic or fetal tissue into people with spinal cord injuries appears to be safe (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: When my son asked me what his 14-month-old twin sons had eaten while I was baby-sitting, I rattled off the food he had left for them, then added that they had also eaten some of my yogurt and prunes. ''Prunes!'' he exclaimed in horror. ''You gave them prunes? They could choke on prunes!'' ''Of course,'' I calmly explained, hoping I would not be fired as a caretaker for my darling grandsons, ''I didn't give them whole prunes or prunes with pits. I gave them prune mush from well-stewed prunes. They couldn't possibly choke on that.''

headline.main: Simple Strategies for a Choke-Proof Home

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health on choking, and what to do to assist someone who is choking; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: At a recent conference at the hospital where I work, a senior cardiology fellow started things off with the following case: an 82-year-old man with worsening chest pains had been transferred to our hospital to have coronary bypass surgery. He had diabetes, high blood pressure, poor kidney function and anemia, and in the past he had suffered a heart attack, a stroke and congestive heart failure. Could the surgeons operate? The patient was clearly a high-risk surgical candidate because of his medical problems. After some discussion, followed by a review of the patient's coronary angiogram by the doctors in the room, it was decided that surgery was too risky and that his heart disease should be treated with medication alone.

headline.main: Life and Death Stakes in the Numbers Game

docs.abstract: Pressures on cardiac surgeons to produce good results has become tremendous, raising concerns about whether some of sickest patients are being denied surgery that may help them (M)
